Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that the U.S. trade deficit is at an all-time high under Trump in the last three years, without considering the trade surplus in services.
Understate: The claim understates the fact that the trade deficit in goods was higher under Trump in 2018 and 2019 than during any previous year.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not providing enough support or evidence to back up the statement.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support or data to fully substantiate the assertion that the U.S. trade deficit is at an all-time high under Trump.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the trade deficit in goods alone is the only important factor to consider, without acknowledging the deficit in goods and services.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations, such as the deficit in goods and services being larger under previous administrations.
